Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transcriptional regulation of neuronal polarity and morphogenesis

Neurons are highly polarized cells with distinct structures and functions localized mainly to either end of the cell. They are also intricately shaped and engage in myriad movements during development. These features and processes are indispensable for the neuron to engage in its function of transmitting the directional flow of information through a neural circuit. However, little is known about how neuronal polarization and morphogenesis is regulated in vivo. This research will take advantage of the small size and experimental accessibility of sea squirt embryos to understand how these processes are regulated. Sea squirts, or ascidians, are the invertebrates most closely related to vertebrates and have emerged as a model organism for the study of animal development. More specifically, the research will focus on connecting the gene regulatory network, the basic blueprint of the embryo, to processes occurring during neural development such as polarization, migration, axon guidance, and morphogenesis. The hope is to identify rate-limiting genes involved in such processes, and their regulation by upstream genes which might be playing a similar role in vertebrates. Thus, the overall aim is to understand how each neuron is precisely shaped and formed as dictated by the gene regulatory network.

The Fellow is dedicated to engaging and inspiring other Latinos as they pursue a scientific career. Students from underrepresented groups will be provided opportunities to participate in the research where possible. The project will take advantage of being located at a visible institution in a diverse city such as New York to reach out to underrepresented minorities not directly pursuing a career in science, through lectures, open forums, workshops, group visits, and other events that will stimulate their interest in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We were interested in studying sea squirt embryos because they are small, transparent, and develop in under 16 hours, but also because sea squirts are our closest invertebrate relatives, and can help us learn much about the origins of the heart, brain, skull, liver, thyroid, and other specialized organs that have helped vertebrates, in particular humans, become so successful.

There were three major intellectual outcomes from this project: 1) We discovered that the sea squirt have cells that may represent a prototype of the "Neural Crest", which is an important group of cells in our embryos that generates much of our skull, jaws, and sensory systems. 2) Our investigations of this rudimentary Neural Crest showed that it gives rise to a particular sensory nerve cell, the "Bipolar Tail Neuron", which engages in a series of striking behaviors such as directed movement and shape changes that make the cell go from a small, rounded cell to a very long, stretched out nerve. We were able to image these processes in great detail, showing that these cells have a defined polarity to them. We showed that the precise control of this polarity over time may be important for the cells' behavior. Cell movement and shape change are very important for the development of animal brains and sensory systems, but little is know about how these mechanisms are genetically controled. We have thus established the Bipolar Tail Neurons as a model for studying these processes in live, intact embryos. 3) We discovered among different species of sea squirts a surprisingly radical turnover in the mechanisms that control gene activity. This was highly unexpected due to the fact these different species have nearly identical embryos. What this finding seems to indicate is that the genomic "code" for the control of gene activity is highly flexible, a counterintuitive finding based on current thinking in the field. It is generally assumed that similar gene activity patterns are the result of similar genomic codes, but we showed that the underlying code can be completely rewritten and the activity is still preserved. This phenomenon may have only been uncovered in the sea squirts thanks to the unique fact that their embryos are nearly identical yet their genomes are completely different; in most other groups of animals, embryo divergence is proportional to genome divergence. Our finding has implications for synthetic biology applications, suggesting that there can be multiple ways to rewire a biological process.

The broader impact from the project comes mostly from our outreach activity, in particular with the New York Harbor School, an innovative public high school centered on marine trades and sciences. We collaborated with teachers at the New York Harbor School to bolster their Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) and Marine Biology programs. We mentored students as they undertook independent research projects related to our project on sea squirts. We also served as volunteer members of the school's professional advisory committee, bringing our expertise to the students by helping them formulate research questions and evaluating their scientific proposals, assignments, and general STEM education. The majority of students at the school come from racial and ethnic groups that are under-represented in STEM professions. We hope that this engagement of high school students in cutting edge marine biology research could serve as a model for increasing diversity of students in STEM fields in higher education.
